title: TCP vs UDP
content: TCP is connection-oriented and reliable
UDP is connectionless and lower latency
TCP guarantees delivery and order; UDP does not
TCP uses flow and congestion control; UDP leaves it to the app

title: IPv4 vs IPv6
content: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses (e.g., 192.168.1.1)
IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses (hexadecimal)
IPv4 addresses ran out; IPv6 provides near-infinite space
IPv6 includes built-in security features like IPsec

title: HTTP vs HTTPS
content: HTTP transmits data in plain text
HTTPS encrypts data using TLS/SSL
HTTPS protects against man-in-the-middle attacks
Browsers mark HTTP sites as 'Not Secure'

title: SSD vs HDD
content: HDDs use spinning magnetic platters and read/write heads
SSDs use flash memory with no moving parts
SSDs are significantly faster and more durable
HDDs are generally cheaper per gigabyte

title: RAM vs ROM
content: RAM is volatile; data is lost when power is off
ROM is non-volatile; data retains without power
RAM stores active programs and data for the CPU
ROM stores firmware and boot instructions

title: How DNS Works
content: DNS acts as the phonebook of the internet
Translates domain names (google.com) to IP addresses
Uses a hierarchy: Root, TLD (.com), and Authoritative servers
Caching helps speed up lookups locally

title: What is a VPN?
content: Creates an encrypted tunnel between you and a remote server
Masks your IP address and location
Secures data on public WiFi networks
Can bypass geo-restrictions on content

title: Compiler vs Interpreter
content: Compilers translate code to machine language all at once
Interpreters translate and execute code line-by-line
Compiled code runs faster but takes longer to build
Interpreted code is easier to debug and is platform-independent

title: What is an API?
content: Application Programming Interface allows apps to talk to each other
Defines requests and responses for software interaction
REST and GraphQL are common API architectural styles
Hides internal complexity while exposing functionality

title: Cookies vs Cache
content: Cookies store user data (login, preferences) sent to the server
Cache stores resources (images, scripts) locally for speed
Cookies track sessions; Cache reduces bandwidth usage
Cookies expire; Cache can be cleared manually or by age

title: Cores vs Threads
content: A Core is a physical processing unit on the CPU
A Thread is a virtual sequence of instructions
Hyper-threading allows one core to handle two threads
More cores help with heavy multitasking; threads improve efficiency

title: What is Git?
content: A distributed version control system
Tracks changes in source code over time
Allows branching and merging for parallel development
GitHub and GitLab are hosting services for Git repositories

title: SaaS vs PaaS vs IaaS
content: IaaS: Infrastructure (servers, storage) you rent (e.g., AWS EC2)
PaaS: Platform tools for building apps (e.g., Heroku)
SaaS: Finished software delivered over web (e.g., Gmail, Slack)
Difference lies in how much 'stack' you manage vs the provider

title: 2FA vs MFA
content: 2FA requires two forms of identification
MFA requires two or more forms
Factors: Something you know, have, or are (biometrics)
Significantly reduces risk of unauthorized access

title: Blockchain Simplified
content: A decentralized, distributed digital ledger
Records transactions across many computers
Once recorded, data cannot be altered retroactively
Fundamental technology behind cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin

title: Open Source vs Closed Source
content: Open source code is public and modifiable (e.g., Linux)
Closed source code is proprietary and private (e.g., Windows)
Open source often relies on community support
Closed source usually offers official vendor support

title: Modem vs Router
content: Modem connects your home to the ISP (internet source)
Router distributes that signal to devices (WiFi/LAN)
Modem translates analog signals to digital
Many modern devices combine both into a 'Gateway'

title: Lossy vs Lossless Compression
content: Lossy removes data to reduce file size (JPEG, MP3)
Lossless keeps all original data (PNG, FLAC)
Lossy quality degrades with heavy compression
Lossless allows perfect reconstruction of original file

title: USB-C vs Thunderbolt
content: USB-C is a physical connector shape
Thunderbolt is a data transfer protocol
All Thunderbolt 3/4 ports are USB-C, but not vice versa
Thunderbolt supports higher bandwidth and daisy-chaining

title: Containers vs Virtual Machines
content: VMs virtualize hardware; run full OS per instance
Containers virtualize the OS; share the host kernel
Containers (e.g., Docker) are lightweight and start fast
VMs provide stronger isolation but consume more resources

title: Symmetric vs Asymmetric Encryption
content: Symmetric uses one key for encryption and decryption
Asymmetric uses a public key (encrypt) and private key (decrypt)
Symmetric is faster; Asymmetric is more secure for sharing
HTTPS uses both: Asymmetric for handshake, Symmetric for data

title: SQL vs NoSQL
content: SQL databases are relational (tables, rows, columns)
NoSQL databases are non-relational (documents, key-pairs)
SQL is best for structured data and complex queries
NoSQL scales better horizontally for massive, unstructured data

title: Bandwidth vs Latency
content: Bandwidth is the width of the pipe (amount of data per second)
Latency is the speed of travel (time to get there)
High bandwidth doesn't guarantee low latency
Latency matters for gaming; Bandwidth for streaming 4K

title: What is Machine Learning?
content: Subset of AI where computers learn from data without explicit programming
Uses algorithms to find patterns in datasets
Supervised learning uses labeled data; Unsupervised does not
Powers recommendations, voice assistants, and spam filters

title: OLED vs LCD
content: LCD uses a backlight to illuminate pixels
OLED pixels emit their own light
OLED offers true blacks and better contrast
LCDs are generally brighter and cheaper to produce

title: GPU vs CPU
content: CPU: Few powerful cores for sequential processing
GPU: Thousands of smaller cores for parallel processing
CPU handles logic/OS; GPU handles graphics/math
GPUs are essential for gaming and AI model training

title: Static vs Dynamic IP
content: Static IP never changes; manually assigned
Dynamic IP changes periodically; assigned by DHCP
Servers use Static IPs for reliability
Home devices use Dynamic IPs for ease of management

title: What is Phishing?
content: Social engineering attack to steal credentials
Often mimics legitimate emails (banks, login pages)
Spear-phishing targets specific individuals
Check the URL and sender address to spot it

title: What is Markdown?
content: Lightweight markup language for formatting text
Uses symbols like # for headers and * for bold
Converts easily to HTML
Standard for Readme files and developer documentation

title: VR vs AR
content: VR creates a fully immersive digital environment
AR overlays digital elements onto the real world
VR requires a headset blocking real vision (Oculus)
AR can run on phones (Pokemon Go) or glasses

title: What is an Algorithm?
content: A step-by-step set of instructions to solve a problem
Like a recipe for a computer
Can be simple (sorting numbers) or complex (search engine)
Efficiency is measured in Big O notation

title: Client vs Server
content: Client requests services (e.g., your web browser)
Server provides services (e.g., web server hosting a site)
Basis of the Client-Server model
P2P networks enable devices to act as both

title: Frontend vs Backend
content: Frontend is what the user sees and interacts with (UI)
Backend is the logic, database, and server-side processes
Frontend languages: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
Backend languages: Python, Java, Node.js, Go

title: Raster vs Vector Graphics
content: Raster images are made of pixels (JPEG, PNG)
Vector images are made of mathematical paths (SVG, AI)
Raster loses quality when scaled up (pixelation)
Vector scales infinitely without quality loss

title: Internet of Things (IoT)
content: Network of physical objects embedded with sensors
Devices exchange data over the internet
Examples: Smart bulbs, thermostats, industrial sensors
Raises concerns about security and privacy

title: L1/L2/L3 Cache
content: Ultra-fast memory located directly on the CPU
Stores frequently used instructions
L1 is smallest/fastest; L3 is largest/slowest
Reduces time CPU waits for data from RAM

title: What is a Firewall?
content: Network security system monitoring traffic
Acts as a barrier between trusted and untrusted networks
Can be hardware (router) or software (OS level)
Filters packets based on security rules

title: What is Linux?
content: An open-source operating system kernel
Basis for Android, ChromeOS, and most servers
Distributions (Ubuntu, Fedora) package it for users
Known for stability, security, and flexibility

title: Content Delivery Network (CDN)
content: Geographically distributed group of servers
Delivers content from the server closest to the user
Reduces latency and speeds up page loads
Protects origin server from traffic spikes

title: Bluetooth 4 vs 5
content: Bluetooth 5 offers 4x range of 4.2
Bluetooth 5 offers 2x speed of 4.2
5.0 introduced 'Dual Audio' (two headsets at once)
Low Energy (LE) creates efficiency for IoT devices

title: JSON vs XML
content: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is lightweight/easy to read
XML (eXtensible Markup Language) is verbose/document-centric
JSON is the standard for modern APIs
XML supports metadata and schema validation better

title: Deep Web vs Dark Web
content: Deep Web: Anything not indexed by search engines (emails, banking)
Dark Web: Encrypted networks requiring specific browsers (Tor)
Deep Web is 90%+ of the internet; Dark Web is a tiny slice
Dark Web provides anonymity, used for both privacy and crime

title: BIOS/UEFI
content: Firmware used to perform hardware initialization
Runs before the Operating System loads
UEFI is the modern replacement for legacy BIOS
UEFI supports larger drives and faster boot times

title: Fiber vs Copper Cables
content: Copper transmits data via electricity
Fiber transmits data via light pulses
Fiber is faster, travels farther, immune to interference
Copper (Ethernet) is cheaper and more durable for short runs

title: What is a Kernel?
content: The core component of an Operating System
Manages CPU, memory, and peripheral devices
Translates software requests into hardware instructions
Crash in kernel = Blue Screen of Death (system crash)

title: What is Ping?
content: Utility to test reachability of a host on IP network
Measures round-trip time for messages
Uses ICMP protocol
High ping indicates lag in connection

title: What is 5G?
content: Fifth generation of mobile network technology
Offers higher speeds, lower latency, massive capacity
Uses mmWave (fast, short range) and Sub-6 (wide range)
Enables autonomous vehicles and remote surgery

title: NFC (Near Field Communication)
content: Short-range wireless technology (4cm or less)
Used for contactless payments (Apple Pay)
Allows instant pairing of devices
Operates via magnetic field induction

title: ASCII vs Unicode
content: ASCII encodes 128 characters (English only)
Unicode encodes 140,000+ characters (Global languages + Emojis)
UTF-8 is the most common encoding for Unicode
Without Unicode, we couldn't use mixed languages on web

title: DDoS Attack
content: Distributed Denial of Service
Overwhelms a server with fake traffic to crash it
Uses a botnet (network of infected devices)
Disrupts service for legitimate users

title: Hashing vs Encryption
content: Encryption is two-way; data can be decrypted
Hashing is one-way; data cannot be reversed
Encryption is for data transmission/storage
Hashing is for verifying data integrity (passwords)

title: Pixel Density (PPI)
content: Pixels Per Inch measures screen sharpness
Higher PPI means pixels are harder to distinguish
Key factor in 'Retina' displays
Depends on resolution divided by screen size

title: Logical vs Physical Topology
content: Physical: How cables and devices are wired (Star, Bus)
Logical: How data flows through the network
A physical Star network can act like a logical Bus
Determines fault tolerance and troubleshooting

title: Stack vs Heap Memory
content: Stack: Static memory allocation; fast; LIFO structure
Heap: Dynamic memory allocation; slower; flexible size
Stack stores local variables/function calls
Heap stores global variables/objects; requires management

title: Rooting / Jailbreaking
content: Gaining administrative (root) access to a mobile OS
Rooting is for Android; Jailbreaking is for iOS
Allows removal of bloatware and deep customization
voids warranty and creates security risks

title: Serverless Computing
content: Devs write code; Cloud provider manages execution
No need to provision or manage servers
Pay only for the compute time used (e.g., AWS Lambda)
Scales automatically with demand

title: JSON Web Tokens (JWT)
content: Standard for securely transmitting data as JSON
Commonly used for stateless authentication
Contains Header, Payload, and Signature
Allows users to stay logged in without server session storage

title: Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
content: Product with just enough features to satisfy early adopters
Used to test hypotheses with minimal resources
Focuses on core value proposition
Iterative development follows feedback

title: Agile vs Waterfall
content: Waterfall: Linear, sequential phases; rigid
Agile: Iterative, flexible, feedback-loop driven
Waterfall is good for clear, fixed requirements
Agile adapts better to changing needs (Scrum/Kanban)

title: Latency vs Jitter
content: Latency is the delay in data transmission
Jitter is the variance/fluctuation in latency over time
Consistent high latency is manageable
High jitter causes buffering and lag spikes in calls

title: RAID Storage
content: Redundant Array of Independent Disks
Combines multiple drives for speed or redundancy
RAID 0: Speed (striping); RAID 1: Mirroring (safety)
RAID is not a backup solution

title: What is a Proxy Server?
content: Intermediary between user and the internet
Forward Proxy: Protects the client (privacy)
Reverse Proxy: Protects the server (load balancing)
Used for content filtering and caching

title: Optical vs Digital Zoom
content: Optical Zoom: Physical lens movement; no quality loss
Digital Zoom: Cropping and enlarging image; quality loss
Optical is true magnification
Digital is software simulation

title: POP3 vs IMAP vs SMTP
content: SMTP sends email from client to server
POP3 downloads email and deletes from server (single device)
IMAP syncs email across devices (server storage)
IMAP is standard for modern multi-device use

title: Public Key Infrastructure (PKI)
content: Framework for encryption and digital signatures
Public Key: Shared openly to encrypt messages
Private Key: Kept secret to decrypt messages
Foundation of SSL/TLS and secure web browsing

title: System on a Chip (SoC)
content: Integrates all computer components on one chip
Includes CPU, GPU, Memory, Modem, AI engine
Used in phones (Snapdragon) and Apple M-series
High efficiency and compact size

title: Alpha vs Beta Software
content: Alpha: Early stage, internal testing, very buggy
Beta: Feature complete, released to select users for testing
RC (Release Candidate): Potential final version
Gold: Final production version

title: Frame Rate (FPS)
content: Frames Per Second displayed on screen
24fps: Standard for movies (cinematic look)
60fps: Standard for smooth gaming/UI
Higher FPS requires more powerful GPU

title: Refresh Rate (Hz)
content: How many times per second the screen updates
60Hz is standard; 120Hz/144Hz is smoother
Must match FPS for best experience
Variable Refresh Rate (VRR) syncs Hz to FPS

title: Responsive Web Design
content: Websites that adapt to screen size
Uses CSS Media Queries
Ensures usability on mobile, tablet, and desktop
Eliminates need for separate 'm.site.com' versions

title: What is Metadata?
content: Data about data
Example: Photo metadata includes date, camera, location
Example: Email metadata includes sender, receiver, time
Crucial for organization and search

title: How ZIP Works
content: Identifies patterns and repetition in data
Replaces repeated data with shorter references
Lossless compression (original data is restored)
Huffman coding is a common algorithm used

title: Biometric Authentication
content: Using biological traits for ID
Fingerprint, FaceID, Iris scan, Voice rec
Stored as encrypted mathematical models, not images
More convenient than passwords but harder to reset

title: Bug Bounty Programs
content: Companies pay ethical hackers to find flaws
Incentivizes reporting bugs rather than exploiting them
Managed by platforms like HackerOne
Crucial for strengthening security posture

title: CAP Theorem
content: Distributed systems can only provide 2 of 3:
Consistency (all nodes see same data)
Availability (system always responds)
Partition Tolerance (system works if network breaks)
In reality, you choose C or A when P happens

title: Why Dark Mode Saves Battery
content: Only applies to OLED/AMOLED screens
Black pixels are turned off completely
LCDs consume same power regardless of color
Also reduces eye strain in low light

title: SOLID Principles
content: 5 design principles for maintainable OOP code
S: Single Responsibility
O: Open/Closed
L: Liskov Substitution
I: Interface Segregation
D: Dependency Inversion

title: Anatomy of a URL
content: Protocol: https://
Subdomain: www or blog
Domain: google.com
Path: /search/images
Parameters: ?q=cats (query string)

title: Ransomware
content: Malware that encrypts your files
Attacker demands payment (crypto) for decryption key
WannaCry is a famous example
Backups are the only reliable defense

title: Quantum Computing Basics
content: Uses Qubits instead of bits
Qubits can exist in superposition (0 and 1 at once)
Solves specific complex problems exponentially faster
Threatens current encryption standards

title: How Incognito Mode Works
content: Does NOT hide activity from ISP or websites
Prevents browser from saving history/cookies locally
Good for logging into public computers
Sessions are isolated from main browser profile

title: FinTech
content: Financial Technology
Mobile banking, investing apps, crypto
Disrupts traditional banking models
Examples: PayPal, Stripe, Robinhood

title: Dead vs Stuck Pixels
content: Dead Pixel: Does not light up (black spot)
Stuck Pixel: Fixed on one color (red/green/blue)
Stuck pixels can sometimes be fixed by flashing colors
Dead pixels are usually permanent hardware failure

title: Zigbee vs Z-Wave vs Matter
content: Wireless mesh protocols for smart home
Zigbee: 2.4GHz, open standard
Z-Wave: 900MHz, proprietary, better range
Matter: New unifying standard to make them all work together

title: Third-Party Cookies
content: Cookies set by a domain other than the one you are visiting
Used primarily for cross-site tracking and ads
Being phased out by major browsers (Chrome, Safari)
Reason why you see ads for things you just searched

title: x86 vs ARM
content: x86 (Intel/AMD): Complex Instruction Set (CISC), high power
ARM (Apple/Mobile): Reduced Instruction Set (RISC), high efficiency
x86 dominated PCs; ARM dominated phones
Lines blurring with Apple M-series and Windows on ARM

title: Data Center Tiers
content: Ranking system for data center uptime
Tier 1: Basic capacity, ~99.6% uptime
Tier 4: Fully fault-tolerant, 99.995% uptime
Higher tiers require redundant power and cooling

title: Software vs Firmware
content: Software: Programs you install/change often
Firmware: Low-level code embedded in hardware
Firmware controls the device's basic functions
Updating firmware is riskier (bricking risk)

title: The Onion Router (Tor)
content: Directs traffic through a volunteer overlay network
Uses triple-layer encryption (like an onion)
Hides user's location and usage from surveillance
Slow speed due to multiple hops

title: Source Code vs Machine Code
content: Source Code: Human-readable (Python, C++)
Machine Code: Binary (0s and 1s) CPU understands
Compilation/Interpretation bridges the gap
You edit source code; you run machine code

title: Bandwidth Throttling
content: Intentional slowing of internet service by ISP
Used to manage network congestion
Can target specific traffic (e.g., torrents, heavy streaming)
VPNs can sometimes bypass content-based throttling

title: Hot Swapping
content: Replacing components without shutting down system
USB drives are hot-swappable
Server hard drives are often hot-swappable
RAM and CPUs are generally NOT hot-swappable

title: Air vs Liquid Cooling
content: Air: Heatsink and fans; simple, reliable, louder
Liquid: Pump, radiator, coolant; efficient, quieter
Liquid handles extreme heat better (overclocking)
Air cooling has zero risk of leaks

title: Software Telemetry
content: Automatic data collection from software usage
Helps developers fix crashes and improve features
Often opt-out in settings
Privacy concern if personal data is included

title: Load Balancing
content: Distributes network traffic across multiple servers
Prevents any single server from crashing
Improves responsiveness and availability
Can use Round Robin or Least Connections algorithms

title: Ray Tracing
content: Rendering technique simulating physical light behavior
Calculates paths of individual light rays
Produces realistic reflections, shadows, and refraction
Computationally expensive; requires specialized hardware (RTX)

title: CAPTCHA
content: Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart
Prevents bots from spamming forms
evolved from distorted text to 'Click images of buses'
Modern versions analyse mouse movement (reCAPTCHA v3)

title: Hypervisor Type 1 vs Type 2
content: Software that creates and runs Virtual Machines (VMs)
Type 1 (Bare Metal): Runs directly on hardware (ESXi)
Type 2 (Hosted): Runs as app on OS (VirtualBox)
Type 1 is for servers; Type 2 is for personal use

title: What is DevOps?
content: Cultural philosophy combining Development and Operations
Goal: Shorten development life cycle
Uses CI/CD (Continuous Integration/Deployment)
Breaks down silos between coders and admins

title: Bloatware
content: Unwanted software pre-installed on a new device
Takes up storage and RAM; slows down system
Often trial versions of antivirus or games
Can usually be uninstalled or disabled

title: The TLS Handshake
content: Process to start a secure HTTPS session
Client and Server agree on encryption version
Server sends certificate; Client verifies it
Session keys are generated for the conversation

title: Mechanical vs Membrane Keyboards
content: Membrane: Squishy rubber domes; quiet, cheap, less durable
Mechanical: Individual physical switches; tactile, loud, durable
Mechanical switches come in colors (Red=Linear, Blue=Clicky)
Membrane is common in laptops; Mechanical preferred by gamers

title: HDMI vs DisplayPort
content: HDMI: Ubiquitous on TVs and consoles; carries audio+video
DisplayPort: Common on PC monitors; supports higher refresh rates
DisplayPort supports daisy-chaining multiple monitors
HDMI 2.1 is needed for 4K at 120Hz on consoles

title: NVMe vs SATA SSDs
content: SATA: Older interface; capped at ~600MB/s speed
NVMe: Connects via PCIe; speeds up to 7,000MB/s+
SATA drives look like 2.5 inch disks; NVMe looks like RAM sticks (M.2)
NVMe significantly reduces game load times and boot speed

title: Panel Types: IPS vs TN vs VA
content: TN (Twisted Nematic): Fastest response, poor colors/viewing angles
IPS (In-Plane Switching): Best colors/angles, slower response (historically)
VA (Vertical Alignment): Best contrast/blacks, slower response
IPS is the modern standard for general use

title: Active Noise Cancellation (ANC)
content: Microphones listen to outside noise
Headphones generate an 'anti-noise' sound wave
The two waves cancel each other out (destructive interference)
Best for low, constant droning sounds (airplanes)

title: eSIM vs Physical SIM
content: eSIM is embedded directly into the phone's motherboard
Allows switching carriers via software settings
Enables dual-SIM usage easily (one physical, one digital)
Harder to physically swap between phones quickly

title: Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS)
content: Battery backup that kicks in instantly during power outage
Protects hardware from surges and unclean power
Gives you time to save work and shut down gracefully
Essential for servers and desktop PCs

title: 3D Printing: FDM vs SLA
content: FDM: Melts plastic filament layer by layer (cheaper, hobbyist)
SLA: Cures liquid resin with UV laser (high detail, messy)
FDM is stronger for functional parts
SLA is better for miniatures and jewelry

title: Mouse DPI
content: Dots Per Inch measures mouse sensitivity
High DPI = Cursor moves further with less hand movement
Gamers often use low DPI for precision aiming
Marketing often hypes uselessly high numbers (20,000+)

title: NAS vs DAS
content: DAS (Direct Attached): Plugged via USB (e.g., external hard drive)
NAS (Network Attached): Connected to WiFi/Router
NAS allows multiple users/devices to access files at once
NAS can run apps like Plex or backups automatically

title: Mesh Wi-Fi
content: Uses multiple nodes to blanket a home in Wi-Fi
Single network name (SSID) unlike range extenders
Devices hand off seamlessly between nodes
Fixes dead zones in large houses

title: MAC Address
content: Media Access Control address
Unique hardware ID assigned to every network card
Format: MM:MM:MM:SS:SS:SS (Hexadecimal)
Used for local network identification, not routing over internet

title: Subnet Mask
content: Divides IP address into Network and Host parts
Common home mask: 255.255.255.0
Determines how big the local network is
Essential for routing traffic correctly

title: NAT (Network Address Translation)
content: Allows multiple devices to share one Public IP
Router translates private local IPs to public IP
Essential because IPv4 addresses ran out
Acts as a basic firewall by hiding internal IPs

title: What is DHCP?
content: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
Automatically assigns IP addresses to devices joining network
Prevents IP conflicts
Without it, you'd have to manually type IPs for every phone/laptop

title: Port Forwarding
content: Tells router to send specific traffic to a specific device
Required for hosting game servers or accessing home cameras remotely
Opens a hole in the firewall (security risk)
Uses port numbers (e.g., 80 for Web, 25565 for Minecraft)

title: Packet Loss
content: Data travels in small units called packets
Loss occurs when packets fail to reach destination
Causes rubber-banding in games and robotic voice in calls
Caused by congestion, bad cables, or weak Wi-Fi

title: Localhost (127.0.0.1)
content: The loopback address
Refers to 'this computer' you are currently on
Used by developers to test websites before publishing
There's no place like 127.0.0.1

title: Starlink / LEO Internet
content: Low Earth Orbit satellites (550km up)
Much faster/lower latency than traditional geostationary satellite (35k km)
Requires clear view of the sky
Bringing high-speed internet to rural/remote areas

title: WHOIS Lookup
content: Public database of domain name owners
Shows registration date, expiry, and registrar
Often redacted for privacy (GDPR)
Used to check if a domain is available or legitimate

title: What are Drivers?
content: Translator software between OS and Hardware
Tells Windows/macOS how to talk to your printer or GPU
Outdated drivers cause crashes or performance issues
Usually updated automatically now

title: File Systems: NTFS vs exFAT
content: NTFS: Windows standard; supports large files (>4GB); secure
FAT32: Universal compatibility; cannot store files >4GB
exFAT: Modern universal (Win+Mac); supports large files
Use exFAT for USB drives moving between Mac and PC

title: GUI vs CLI
content: GUI (Graphical User Interface): Icons, mouse, windows
CLI (Command Line Interface): Text-based, typing commands
CLI is faster for power users and automation
GUI is easier for beginners and visual tasks

title: Virtual Memory / Swap
content: Using hard drive space as temporary RAM
Prevents crashes when physical RAM runs out
Much slower than real RAM
Thrashing: When disk is overworked moving data to/from swap

title: Safe Mode
content: Diagnostic startup mode for OS
Loads only essential drivers and services
Used to remove malware or fix bad drivers
Screen usually looks low-resolution

title: What is an ISO file?
content: A digital copy of an optical disc (CD/DVD)
Single file containing entire installation media
Used to install Operating Systems (Linux/Windows)
Can be 'mounted' to appear as a virtual drive

title: Task Manager
content: System monitor tool (Ctrl+Shift+Esc)
Shows CPU, RAM, and Disk usage per app
Allows 'Force Quit' of frozen programs
Manage Startup apps to speed up boot time

title: Windows Registry
content: Hierarchical database of low-level settings
Stores options for kernel, drivers, and apps
Editing it can break your system
Don't use 'Registry Cleaners'—they are mostly snake oil

title: Cron Jobs
content: Time-based job scheduler in Unix/Linux
Runs scripts automatically at set times
Example: Run backup script every day at 3 AM
Syntax: * * * * * (Minute Hour Day Month Weekday)

title: Clipboard History
content: Standard copy/paste only remembers the last item
Clipboard managers store history of copied items
Windows (Win+V) has it built-in now
Huge productivity booster for writers/coders

title: Zero Trust Security
content: Security model: 'Never trust, always verify'
Does not assume devices inside the network are safe
Requires continuous authentication for every access request
Replaces old 'castle and moat' perimeter defense

title: SQL Injection (SQLi)
content: Web hacking technique
Attacker enters code into a form input (e.g., login box)
Tricks database into revealing hidden data
Prevented by using 'Prepared Statements' in code

title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
content: Injecting malicious scripts into trusted websites
Script executes in the victim's browser
Can steal cookies, session tokens, or redirect users
Sanitizing user input is the defense

title: Salting Passwords
content: Adding random data (salt) to a password before hashing
Ensures two identical passwords have different hashes
Defends against Rainbow Table attacks
Essential for secure user authentication

title: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM)
content: Attacker intercepts communication between two parties
Can eavesdrop or alter messages
Public Wi-Fi is a common vector
HTTPS is the primary defense against this

title: Air Gapped System
content: A computer physically isolated from the internet/networks
Used for extremely sensitive data (military/nuclear)
Can only be hacked by physical access (USB drive)
Maximum security, minimum convenience

title: Brute Force Attack
content: Guessing passwords by trying every combination
Simple but effective against weak passwords
Thwarted by account lockouts and delay timers
Credential Stuffing is a variation using leaked passwords

title: Keylogger
content: Malware that records every keystroke
Captures passwords, emails, and chats
Can be software or a physical hardware plug
Virtual keyboards (clicking screen) help bypass them

title: Sandboxing
content: Running software in an isolated environment
Prevents code from touching the host system
Web browsers sandbox tabs
Used to test suspicious files safely

title: Zero-Day Exploit
content: Attack targeting a flaw known only to the hacker
Developers have had 'zero days' to fix it
Highly valuable on the black market
Requires emergency patching once discovered

title: IDE vs Text Editor
content: Editor (VS Code, Sublime): Lightweight, fast, needs plugins
IDE (IntelliJ, Visual Studio): Heavy, full-featured suite
IDE includes debugger, compiler, and build tools out of box
Editors are preferred for web dev; IDEs for Java/C#

title: Library vs Framework
content: Library: You call the code (you are in control)
Framework: The code calls you (Inversion of Control)
Library: React, jQuery (tools for specific tasks)
Framework: Angular, Django (defines structure of app)

title: SDK (Software Development Kit)
content: Collection of tools to build for a specific platform
Includes libraries, documentation, and samples
Android SDK is needed to make Android apps
iOS SDK is needed for iPhone apps

title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
content: Paradigm organizing code into 'Objects' (data + methods)
Classes are blueprints for Objects
Core concepts: Inheritance, Encapsulation, Polymorphism
Used in Java, C++, Python

title: Recursion
content: A function that calls itself
Used to solve problems that can be broken into smaller versions
Must have a 'Base Case' to stop loop
Risk: Stack Overflow (infinite recursion)

title: Regular Expressions (Regex)
content: Sequence of characters defining a search pattern
Used for string validation (email format) and find/replace
Cryptic syntax (e.g., ^[a-zA-Z0-9]+$)
Extremely powerful but hard to read

title: Technical Debt
content: Cost of choosing an easy solution now vs a better one later
Like financial debt, you pay 'interest' (extra work later)
Caused by rushing features or skipping testing
Must be paid down via Refactoring

title: Refactoring
content: Restructuring code without changing its external behavior
Improving readability and reducing complexity
Cleaning up 'messy' code
Essential for long-term project health

title: Spaghetti Code
content: Unstructured and difficult-to-maintain code
Flow tangles like a bowl of spaghetti
Caused by lack of planning or experience
Uses too many GOTO statements (historically)

title: Null Pointer/Reference
content: Variable that points to nothing (no value)
Accessing it causes a crash (NullPointerException)
Called the 'Billion Dollar Mistake' by its inventor
Modern languages use Optionals to handle this safely

title: What is Big Data?
content: Datasets too large/complex for traditional processing
The 3 Vs: Volume, Velocity, Variety
Requires distributed processing (Hadoop, Spark)
Used for predictive analytics and AI training

title: Data Mining
content: Discovering patterns in large datasets
Uses statistics and machine learning
Example: Supermarket finding beer and diapers are bought together
Transforming raw data into useful information

title: ETL (Extract, Transform, Load)
content: Process of moving data from source to storage
Extract: Pull data from API/DB
Transform: Clean and format data
Load: Save into Data Warehouse
Foundation of data engineering pipelines

title: CSV Files
content: Comma Separated Values
Simple text format for tabular data
Universally readable by Excel, Python, SQL
No formatting, just raw data

title: Primary vs Foreign Key
content: Primary Key: Unique ID for a row in a table
Foreign Key: Reference to a Primary Key in another table
Links tables together (Relational Database)
Ensures data integrity (can't delete parent with children)

title: ACID Properties
content: Guarantee for reliable database transactions
Atomicity: All or nothing
Consistency: Valid state only
Isolation: Transactions don't interfere
Durability: Saved data survives power loss

title: CRUD Operations
content: Basic functions of persistent storage
Create, Read, Update, Delete
Maps to HTTP methods (POST, GET, PUT, DELETE)
Every basic app is just a CRUD interface

title: Data Lake vs Data Warehouse
content: Warehouse: Structured, processed data (ready for analysis)
Lake: Raw, unstructured data (dumped for later)
Warehouse is like a library; Lake is like a junkyard
Lake is cheaper storage; Warehouse is faster query

title: Database Schema
content: The skeleton/structure of a database
Defines tables, fields, and relationships
Can be rigid (SQL) or flexible (NoSQL)
Designing schema is the first step in backend dev

title: Database Indexing
content: Data structure improving retrieval speed
Like an index at the back of a book
Speeds up SELECT queries significantly
Slows down WRITE operations (needs updating)
Crucial for performance optimization

title: The DOM (Document Object Model)
content: Tree structure representing a webpage
Browsers create it from HTML
JavaScript manipulates the DOM to change page content
Virtual DOM (React) is a faster copy for updates

title: HTTP Status Codes
content: 200: OK (Success)
301: Moved Permanently (Redirect)
404: Not Found (Client Error)
500: Internal Server Error (Server Error)

title: User Agent
content: String sent by browser to identify itself
Tells server OS, browser version, and device type
Used to serve mobile vs desktop sites
Can be spoofed for privacy or testing

title: WebAssembly (Wasm)
content: Binary instruction format for web browsers
Allows C++/Rust code to run in browser near native speed
Enables high-performance apps like video editors on web
Works alongside JavaScript, doesn't replace it

title: RSS (Really Simple Syndication)
content: Feed format for publishing updates (blogs, podcasts)
Allows aggregating news from many sites into one reader
Decentralized alternative to social media feeds
Still powers almost all podcast apps

title: Single Page Application (SPA)
content: Web app that loads one HTML page
Updates content dynamically as user interacts
Feels like a native app (no page reloads)
Examples: Gmail, Facebook, Trello

title: Progressive Web App (PWA)
content: Website that behaves like a mobile app
Installable to home screen; works offline
Uses Service Workers for caching
Cheaper to build than separate iOS/Android apps

title: Local Storage vs Session Storage
content: Both store data in browser (key-value pairs)
Session Storage: Cleared when tab is closed
Local Storage: Persists until manually cleared
Neither is secure for passwords (accessible via JS)

title: Semantic HTML
content: Using tags that explain meaning (Header, Article, Footer)
Instead of generic Divs everywhere
Crucial for Screen Readers (Accessibility)
Improves SEO ranking

title: iFrame
content: Inline Frame: Embedding a webpage inside another
Used for YouTube videos, Maps, Ads
Security risk if not sandboxed properly
A window into another domain

title: Neural Networks
content: Computing system inspired by biological brains
Layers of nodes (neurons) process input to output
Deep Learning = Many layers (Deep Neural Net)
Foundation of modern AI (recognition, generation)

title: Deep Learning
content: Subset of ML using multi-layered neural networks
Learns from vast amounts of unstructured data
Powers self-driving cars and AlphaGo
Requires massive GPU power for training

title: Natural Language Processing (NLP)
content: AI branch focusing on human language
Tasks: Translation, Sentiment Analysis, Chatbots
Challenges: Sarcasm, idioms, context
Transformers (like GPT) revolutionized NLP

title: The Turing Test
content: Test of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior
Can a human evaluator distinguish machine from human?
Proposed by Alan Turing in 1950
Modern AI passes it regularly; relevance is debated

title: Deepfakes
content: Synthetic media replacing a person's likeness
Uses GANs (Generative Adversarial Networks)
Used for entertainment, satire, and misinformation
Creating major legal and ethical challenges

title: Large Language Models (LLMs)
content: AI trained on massive text datasets
Predicts the next word in a sequence
Examples: GPT-4, Claude, Llama
Capable of reasoning, coding, and creative writing

title: Computer Vision
content: Enabling computers to 'see' and interpret images
Used in facial recognition, medical imaging, robotics
Object Detection identifies items in a frame
Segmentation outlines exact shapes

title: Edge Computing
content: Processing data near where it is created (the 'edge')
Instead of sending everything to a central cloud
Reduces latency and bandwidth use
Vital for IoT and autonomous vehicles

title: Digital Twin
content: Virtual replica of a physical object or system
Real-time data updates the digital model
Used to simulate changes before applying to real world
Common in manufacturing and jet engines

title: OSI Model
content: 7 Layers of networking
Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, Application
Mnemonic: Please Do Not Throw Sausage Pizza Away
Helps diagnose where a connection fails

title: Scrum Framework
content: Agile methodology for managing work
Work is divided into Sprints (usually 2 weeks)
Daily Stand-up meetings for status updates
Roles: Product Owner, Scrum Master, Team

title: Kanban
content: Visual workflow management method
Columns: To Do, In Progress, Done
Focuses on limiting Work In Progress (WIP)
Originates from Toyota manufacturing

title: A/B Testing
content: Comparing two versions of a webpage/app
Group A sees Version 1; Group B sees Version 2
Measures which performs better (conversion rate)
Data-driven decision making

title: KPI (Key Performance Indicator)
content: Measurable value demonstrating effectiveness
Tech KPIs: Uptime, Bug count, User retention
Must be specific and time-bound
Used to track progress toward goals

title: Churn Rate
content: Percentage of customers who stop using a service
Critical metric for SaaS companies
High churn = leaky bucket (unsustainable)
Focus is on retention to lower churn

title: H.264 vs H.265 (HEVC)
content: Video compression standards (Codecs)
H.264 (AVC): Universal compatibility, larger files
H.265 (HEVC): Better compression (smaller files), same quality
H.265 requires more processing power to play/edit

title: Bitrate
content: Amount of data processed per second in media
Higher bitrate = better quality = larger file size
YouTube compresses bitrate heavily
Blu-ray has much higher bitrate than Netflix

title: RAW vs JPEG
content: JPEG: Processed, compressed, ready to share
RAW: Unprocessed sensor data, large files
RAW allows recovering shadows/highlights in editing
Professional photographers shoot RAW

title: HDR (High Dynamic Range)
content: Expands range between darkest and lightest parts
Provides more vivid colors and brighter highlights
Requires HDR content and HDR-capable screen
Standards: HDR10, Dolby Vision

title: Aspect Ratio
content: Proportion of width to height
16:9: Standard widescreen (TVs, YouTube)
21:9: Ultrawide (Movies, Gaming)
9:16: Vertical video (TikTok, Stories)

title: Transcoding
content: Converting media from one format/codec to another
Plex transcodes files to play on your specific TV
Can lower quality to fit bandwidth
CPU intensive task

title: Spatial Audio
content: 360-degree sound simulation
Sound seems to come from above and behind, not just L/R
Uses Head Tracking (sound stays at source when you turn head)
Apple and Dolby Atmos are leaders

title: Qi Wireless Charging
content: Universal standard for inductive charging
Uses coils to transfer energy via magnetic field
Slower than cable charging; produces more heat
Qi2 adds magnets (like MagSafe) for alignment

title: Sideloading
content: Installing apps from sources other than official Store
Easy on Android (APK files); hard on iOS
Bypasses app store restrictions and fees
Increases risk of installing malware

title: Locked Bootloader
content: Code ensuring only official OS launches
Locked: Prevents installing custom ROMs/Linux
Unlocked: Allows total control but compromises security
Banking apps often fail if unlocked

title: OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer)
content: Company that makes parts for another company's product
Samsung makes screens for iPhone
Foxconn assembles devices for Apple
OEM licenses often cheaper than Retail versions

title: Planned Obsolescence
content: Designing products to fail or become outdated quickly
Glued batteries, non-upgradable RAM, software slowdowns
Encourages frequent upgrading
Major target of environmental regulation

title: Right to Repair
content: Movement demanding manufacturers provide parts/manuals
Fights against proprietary screws and software locks
Allows consumers and 3rd parties to fix devices
Gaining legal traction in EU and US

title: E-Waste
content: Discarded electronic devices
Contains toxic materials (lead, mercury)
Contains precious metals (gold, copper)
Recycling is difficult; often shipped to developing nations

title: Moore's Law
content: Observation that transistors on a chip double every 2 years
Led to exponential growth in computing power
Slowing down as we reach physical atomic limits
Focus shifting from raw speed to efficiency/cores

title: Cores vs Threads
content: Core: A physical processing unit within the CPU
Thread: A virtual version of a core (Hyper-threading)
More cores = better at heavy multitasking (video editing)
Single-core speed matters most for gaming

title: Clock Speed (GHz)
content: Measures how many cycles a CPU executes per second
3.5 GHz = 3.5 billion cycles per second
Higher is generally faster, but architecture matters more
Base clock vs Boost clock (temporary speed burst)

title: TDP (Thermal Design Power)
content: Maximum heat a component generates under load
measured in Watts
Determines what kind of cooler and power supply you need
High TDP = High Performance = High Heat

title: ARM vs x86 Architecture
content: x86 (Intel/AMD): Complex instructions, high power, dominant in PCs
ARM (Apple Silicon/Qualcomm): Simple instructions, power efficient
ARM is dominant in mobile; now taking over laptops (M1/M2/M3)
Software must be compiled specifically for one or the other

title: FPGA
content: Field-Programmable Gate Array
A chip that can be rewired via software after manufacturing
Used for specific tasks (AI, signal processing) where speed is key
Harder to program than a standard CPU

title: RAID Storage
content: Redundant Array of Independent Disks
RAID 0: Speed (striping), no safety
RAID 1: Safety (mirroring), normal speed
RAID 5: Balance of speed and safety (parity)

title: Thunderbolt vs USB 4
content: Thunderbolt: Intel protocol, 40Gbps, supports external GPUs
USB 4: Based on Thunderbolt 3, universal standard
Both use the USB-C connector shape
Confusing naming conventions (Gen 2x2, etc.)

title: The Silicon Lottery
content: Microscopic manufacturing imperfections make every chip unique
Two identical CPUs might handle overclocking differently
A 'Golden Chip' runs faster at lower voltage
Luck of the draw when buying parts

title: Liquid Cooling vs Air Cooling
content: Air: Heatsink + Fan; reliable, cheap, bulky
AIO (All-In-One) Liquid: Radiator + Pump; cleaner look, efficient
Custom Loop: High maintenance, best performance, very expensive
Liquid has higher thermal capacity than air

title: 80 Plus PSU Ratings
content: Measures power supply efficiency (wall to component)
Tiers: White, Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum, Titanium
Higher tier = less wasted electricity (heat)
Does not strictly indicate quality, just efficiency

title: DNS (Domain Name System)
content: The phonebook of the internet
Translates 'google.com' into IP address '142.250.190.46'
If DNS server fails, you can't load websites by name
Changing DNS (e.g., to 1.1.1.1) can improve speed/privacy

title: IPv4 vs IPv6
content: IPv4: 32-bit addresses (ran out of unique numbers)
IPv6: 128-bit addresses (virtually infinite)
IPv6 removes need for NAT
Adoption is slow because upgrading old hardware is hard

title: SSL / TLS Certificates
content: Encrypts data between browser and server
Represented by the Padlock icon in URL bar
TLS is the modern successor to SSL
Prevents ISPs or hackers from reading your passwords

title: VPN (Virtual Private Network)
content: Creates an encrypted tunnel for your internet traffic
Hides your IP address from websites
Hides your browsing history from your ISP
Used for remote work security and bypassing geo-blocks

title: CDN (Content Delivery Network)
content: Network of servers distributed globally
Stores copies of images/videos closer to users
Speeds up website loading times drastically
Defends against DDoS attacks by absorbing traffic

title: Latency vs Jitter
content: Latency (Ping): Time for data to travel round-trip
Jitter: The variation in latency over time
High jitter causes lag spikes in gaming
Stable high ping is better than unstable low ping

title: SSH (Secure Shell)
content: Protocol for secure remote login to computers
Replaced the insecure Telnet
Uses public/private key pairs for authentication
Essential tool for server administrators

title: 5G: Sub-6 vs mmWave
content: Sub-6: Slight upgrade over 4G; good range, decent speed
mmWave: Insanely fast (Gigabit), very poor range
mmWave is blocked by walls and even rain
Most '5G' icons on phones are utilizing Sub-6

title: Docker / Containers
content: Packages app and dependencies into a 'container'
Runs the same on any machine (laptop or server)
Lighter than a Virtual Machine (no OS overhead)
Solves 'it works on my machine' problem

title: Kubernetes (K8s)
content: System for managing thousands of containers
Auto-scaling: Adds servers when traffic spikes
Self-healing: Restarts crashed containers
Originally designed by Google (Borg)

title: Serverless Computing
content: Running code without managing servers (e.g., AWS Lambda)
You pay only for the milliseconds the code runs
Scales from 0 to 10,000 requests instantly
Servers still exist, but they are the vendor's problem

title: CI/CD Pipeline
content: Continuous Integration / Continuous Deployment
Automates testing and releasing code
Code is built, tested, and pushed to production automatically
Enables companies to update apps multiple times a day

title: Microservices
content: Breaking a big app (Monolith) into small services
User service, Payment service, Cart service run independently
If Payment crashes, the rest of the site stays up
Complex to manage networking between them

title: Infrastructure as Code (IaC)
content: Managing servers using configuration files (Terraform/Ansible)
Prevents 'Configuration Drift' (servers becoming different)
Allows destroying and rebuilding cloud setups in minutes
Treats hardware setup like software code

title: REST API
content: Representational State Transfer
Standard way for computers to talk over HTTP
Stateless: Server doesn't remember previous requests
Uses standard methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE

title: GraphQL
content: Modern alternative to REST APIs
Client asks exactly for data it needs, nothing more
Fixes 'Over-fetching' (downloading too much data)
Single endpoint instead of multiple URLs

title: Git
content: Distributed Version Control System
Tracks every change made to code history
Allows 'Branching' to experiment safely
GitHub/GitLab are hosting services for Git

title: JSON vs XML
content: Formats for data exchange
XML: Like HTML, verbose, strict, supports metadata
JSON: Lightweight, readable, maps to code objects
JSON has largely replaced XML for web APIs

title: Compiled vs Interpreted
content: Compiled (C++, Rust): Code translates to machine code beforehand; faster run
Interpreted (Python, JS): Code translates line-by-line while running; slower
Java uses both (Compiles to Bytecode, Interpreted by JVM)
Compiled languages allow for better optimization

title: Hash Functions
content: One-way math algorithm (e.g., SHA-256)
Turns any input into a fixed string of characters
Changing one comma in input changes entire hash
Used for verifying file integrity and storing passwords

title: ASCII vs Unicode
content: ASCII: 7-bit code, supports English text only (128 chars)
Unicode: Supports every language + Emojis (140,000+ chars)
UTF-8 is the standard encoding for Unicode on web
Mojibake: Garbage text when encoding is mismatched

title: Binary and Hexadecimal
content: Binary (Base 2): 0s and 1s; native language of processors
Hex (Base 16): 0-9 and A-F; compact way to read binary
One Hex digit represents 4 bits (a nibble)
Used for Color Codes (#FF5733) and Memory Addresses

title: Stack vs Heap Memory
content: Stack: Fast, orderly, temporary variables; size limit
Heap: Slower, messy, large objects; manual management
Stack Overflow happens when the stack runs out of room
Memory Leaks happen in the Heap

title: Big O Notation
content: Describes how an algorithm slows down as data grows
O(1): Instant; O(n): Linear; O(n^2): Slow/Exponential
Used to evaluate code efficiency/scalability
Essential for coding interviews

title: MFA / 2FA
content: Multi-Factor Authentication
Something you know (password) + Something you have (phone)
SMS 2FA is insecure (SIM swapping)
Authenticator Apps or Hardware Keys (YubiKey) are best

title: Biometric Security
content: Using biological traits for ID (Fingerprint, FaceID)
Convenient but you cannot 'change' your fingerprint if stolen
stored as a mathematical hash, not an image
U.S. law treats biometrics differently than passwords

title: Ransomware
content: Malware that encrypts your files
Attacker demands payment (crypto) for the decryption key
Targeting hospitals and cities recently
Backups are the only reliable defense

title: Botnets
content: Network of infected computers (zombies) controlled remotely
Used to launch DDoS attacks or mine crypto
IoT devices (fridges, cameras) are often recruited
Owners often don't know their device is part of a botnet

title: Honeypot
content: Decoy system set up to attract hackers
Contains fake data but looks real
Used to study attacker behavior and techniques
Distracts hackers from the real valuable servers

title: PGP (Pretty Good Privacy)
content: Standard for encrypting emails and files
Uses Public Key (to encrypt) and Private Key (to decrypt)
Allows 'signing' messages to prove identity
Trust model: Web of Trust

title: Social Engineering
content: Hacking the human, not the machine
Manipulating people into giving up passwords
Pretexting: Pretending to be IT support or CEO
Often more effective than technical hacking

title: Phishing
content: Fraudulent emails aiming to steal credentials
Spear Phishing: Targeted at a specific person
Whaling: Targeted at high-profile execs
Check the sender URL carefully

title: How Blockchain Works
content: Distributed, immutable ledger of transactions
Blocks are linked using hashes of previous blocks
Requires consensus from network to add data
Eliminates need for a central bank/intermediary

title: Proof of Work vs Proof of Stake
content: Mechanisms to agree on valid transactions
PoW (Bitcoin): Energy intensive; miners solve math puzzles
PoS (Ethereum): Efficient; validators 'stake' coins as collateral
PoS reduces energy consumption by ~99%

title: Smart Contracts
content: Self-executing code on a blockchain
If X happens, then Y happens automatically
Immutable: Cannot be changed once deployed
Powers DeFi (Decentralized Finance) apps

title: Cold Storage (Wallets)
content: Storing cryptocurrency offline (USB or Paper)
Hot Wallet: Connected to internet (Exchange/App)
Cold Wallet: Immune to online hacking
Key phrase: 'Not your keys, not your coins'

title: NFT (Non-Fungible Token)
content: Unique digital certificate of ownership
Fungible = Bitcoin (swappable); Non-Fungible = Mona Lisa
Stores metadata (link to image) on blockchain
Usage expanding to tickets and deeds, beyond art

title: Quantum Computing
content: Uses Qubits instead of Bits
Superposition: Qubits can be 0 and 1 simultaneously
Entanglement: Instant connection between particles
Threatens to break current encryption standards

title: AR vs VR vs MR
content: VR (Virtual): Fully immersive digital world
AR (Augmented): Digital overlay on real world (Pokemon Go)
MR (Mixed): Digital objects interact with real world
XR (Extended Reality): Umbrella term for all three

title: Haptic Feedback
content: Tactile response (vibration) from device
Linear Resonant Actuators provide precise 'clicks'
Used in touchscreens to simulate buttons
Advanced haptics can simulate texture

title: Brain-Computer Interface (BCI)
content: Direct communication pathway between brain and machine
Can restore motor function to paralyzed limbs
Invasive (implants) vs Non-invasive (EEG caps)
Ethical concerns regarding privacy of thought

title: Solid State Batteries
content: Replaces liquid electrolyte with solid material
Higher energy density and faster charging
Non-flammable (safer than Lithium-Ion)
Holy grail for Electric Vehicles

title: Autonomous Driving Levels
content: Level 0: No automation
Level 2: Hands-off but eyes-on (Tesla Autopilot)
Level 3: Eyes-off in specific situations
Level 5: No steering wheel needed (Full Self-Driving)

title: Graphene
content: Single layer of carbon atoms arranged in honeycomb
200x stronger than steel, best conductor of electricity
Potential to revolutionize chips and batteries
Currently difficult to mass produce

title: The Kernel
content: The core of an Operating System
Complete control over everything in the system
Manages CPU, Memory, and Devices for apps
Linux is a kernel; Android is the OS built on it

title: BIOS vs UEFI
content: Firmware that starts the computer before the OS
BIOS: Legacy, text-only, slower boot
UEFI: Modern, graphical mouse support, Secure Boot
UEFI supports hard drives larger than 2TB

title: Open Source Licenses
content: MIT: Do whatever you want, just credit me
GPL (Copyleft): If you use this, your code must also be open
Apache: Similar to MIT but covers patent rights
Choosing the wrong license can have legal consequences

title: Bloatware
content: Pre-installed unwanted software on new devices
Takes up space and slows down system
Paid for by third parties (e.g., antivirus trials)
Can usually be uninstalled, sometimes requires tools

title: Cookies: 1st vs 3rd Party
content: 1st Party: Set by the site you visit (keeps you logged in)
3rd Party: Set by advertisers tracking you across web
Browsers are phasing out 3rd Party cookies
Fingerprinting is replacing cookies for tracking

title: Browser Cache
content: Storage of temporary files (images, scripts)
Speeds up browsing by not re-downloading static assets
Clearing cache fixes display errors on updated sites
Hard Refresh (Ctrl+F5) bypasses cache

title: Deep Web vs Dark Web
content: Deep Web: Anything behind a login (Email, Banking) - 90% of web
Dark Web: Encrypted networks (Tor) requiring special software
Dark Web hosts illegal markets but also whistleblowers
Surface Web is what Google can index

title: Torrenting (P2P)
content: Peer-to-Peer file sharing
Files are split into pieces and shared among users
Seeder: Has full file; Leecher: Downloading file
Legal technology often used for illegal piracy

title: Webhooks
content: Reverse API: Server tells you when something happens
Don't call us, we'll call you
Used for payment notifications (Stripe) or discord bots
More efficient than polling (asking repeatedly)

title: CAPTCHA
content: Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart
Prevents bots from spamming forms
reCAPTCHA trains AI (identifying traffic lights)
Modern versions look at mouse movement behavior

title: OCR (Optical Character Recognition)
content: Converts images of text into editable text
Used for scanning documents and translating street signs
Mobile banking uses it for check deposits
Early versions required specific fonts

title: AGI (Artificial General Intelligence)
content: Hypothetical AI that matches human cognition across all tasks
Current AI (ANI) is Narrow (good at one thing)
AGI could teach itself new skills without training
The 'Singularity' is when AGI surpasses human intelligence

title: AI Hallucinations
content: When an LLM confidently generates false information
Caused by the model predicting likely words, not facts
Model prioritizes fluency over accuracy
Always verify AI claims with external sources

title: Prompt Engineering
content: Art of crafting inputs to get best AI results
Techniques: Few-shot prompting, Chain of Thought
Garbage In, Garbage Out
Emerging skill set for modern workers

title: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
content: Technique to reduce AI hallucinations
AI searches a trusted database before answering
Combines search engine accuracy with LLM creativity
Used for enterprise chatbots on private data

title: OLED Burn-in
content: Permanent discoloration on screen from static images
OLED pixels degrade unevenly over time
Mitigated by 'Pixel Shift' tech
Avoid leaving news tickers or HUDs on for days

title: Refresh Rate (Hz)
content: How many times per second the screen updates
60Hz = Standard; 144Hz+ = Smooth Gaming
Makes scrolling and animations feel fluid
Higher refresh rate drains battery faster

title: V-Sync vs G-Sync
content: Technologies to prevent Screen Tearing
V-Sync: Locks FPS to monitor Hz (adds input lag)
G-Sync (Nvidia) / FreeSync (AMD): Variable Refresh Rate
Monitor adjusts Hz dynamically to match GPU FPS

title: IP Ratings (Water Resistance)
content: Ingress Protection scale
First digit (Solids/Dust): 6 is dust tight
Second digit (Liquids): 8 is submersion >1m
IP68 is standard for flagships; IPX4 is splash proof

title: USB Naming Confusion
content: USB 3.0 became 3.1 Gen 1, then 3.2 Gen 1 (5Gbps)
USB 3.1 became 3.2 Gen 2 (10Gbps)
Always check the speed (Gbps) not just the name
USB-C is just the shape, not the speed

title: Dark Mode & Battery Life
content: On OLED screens, black pixels are turned off
True black backgrounds save significant battery
On LCD screens, backlight is always on (no saving)
Also reduces eye strain in low light

title: Rootkits
content: Malware designed to hide itself deep in the OS
Operates at Administrator/Kernel level
Can hide other malware from antivirus scans
Often requires wiping the drive to remove

title: NFC (Near Field Communication)
content: Short-range wireless tech (4cm)
Powers Contactless Payments (Apple Pay)
Used for quick pairing of headphones
Can read passive tags (stickers) without power

title: SoC (System on Chip)
content: Integrating all computer components on one chip
CPU + GPU + RAM + Modem in one package
Used in Phones and modern Laptops (Apple Silicon)
High efficiency due to short data distance

title: Incognito Mode
content: Only prevents browser from saving history/cookies
Does NOT hide activity from ISP or Employer
Does NOT hide your IP address
Useful for logging into secondary accounts

title: Tokenization (AI)
